Using and Creating Esri Widgets

Widgets—or as they are known in Angular 1.x, directives—are used and developed in several ways. Out of the box Esri widgets can be loaded and used as-is, Esri view models provide the ability to combine a custom user interface with existing Esri widget logic, and completely custom Angular directives without reference to any widgets or view models can also be developed to work alongside the Esri JSAPI.

Esri Widgets

Widgets are usually comprised of properties, methods, and a user interface. The Esri JSAPI offers a collection of built-in widgets that can be loaded with esriLoader.require() and constructed once there is reference to a MapView or SceneView. This pattern also recommends that you properly tear down and destroy() widgets when Angular scope is being destroyed.

Example:

  • Search

Esri View Models

View models allow for the separation of a widget's methods and properties from its UI presentation. By taking advantage of view models, you can use Esri widget functionality, but apply custom directive templates and styles. For example, the included <esri-home-button> Angular directive makes use of the Esri HomeViewModel in its controller logic but defines its own look and feel.

Example:

  • Home Button

Custom Angular Directives

Directives do not necessarily need to to build directly on top of Esri widget or view model functionality. For instance, the WebScene Slides example page could have been written to separate the slide bookmarks into their own directive; however, the purpose of those example pages is to provide parity with corresponding, authoritative Esri JSAPI examples.

The WebScene Slides with Custom Directive example demonstrates how to encapsulate the slide bookmarks into a custom Angular directive (<esri-webscene-slides>) which has been added to this library.
